de.charite.compbio.jannovar.data

Class ReferenceDictionary

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.charite.compbio.jannovar.data.ReferenceDictionary
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class ReferenceDictionary
extends Object
implements Serializable
    Stores lengths of contigs/chromosomes and a mapping from string to numeric IDs. Often, there are various circulating versions of a genome release. While they all have the same sequence for the chromosomes and contigs (and thus the same length), the names might vary slightly. For example, RefSeq names the human chromosomes as "1", "2" etc. and UCSC names them "chr1", "chr2" etc. The mitochondrial chromosome is called "MT" by RefSeq and "chrM" by UCSC. Further, sometimes RefSeq identifiers such as "NC_000001.10" are used as contig files when mapping. The purpose of this class is to
    1. Assign numeric identifiers to the chromosome names through contigID. Possibly, more than one name is assigned the same numeric id. Usually, numeric ids are assigned starting with 1 (as to correspond to the chromosome names for human/mouse genomes, for example), but arbitrary numeric ids can be assigned (even non-continous sequence).
    2. Assign a primary name to each numeric identifier through contigName.
    3. Assign a length to each contig through contigLength. This is used for coordinate transformation from forward to reverse strand. This means that the genome position and interval types keep a reference to a central ReferenceDictionary object.
        4. This class is immutable which makes it safe to share it between many other objects. You can easily construct objects of its type using ReferenceDictionaryBuilder.
    Author:
    Manuel Holtgrewe
    See Also:
    Serialized Form
